App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly identifies that, under Massachusetts law, the guiding principle in custody determinations is always the child’s best interests, and it evaluates whether foreign custody law is in “substantial conformity” by asking if the foreign court applies a best‑interests standard as understood in Massachusetts. It further describes the best‑interests inquiry as “child-centered,” focused on the child’s specific needs and interests, thereby affirming that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody decisions. This aligns with the proposition for which the case is cited.
El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 50.relevant_excerpt: “In determining the question of ‘substantial conformity’ with Massachusetts law, we look to whether, under the applicable law of Lebanon, the court must consider ‘the best interests of the child[], as that standard is understood under the laws of the Commonwealth.’ … This is true whether considering an original judgment awarding custody or a modification judgment showing changed circumstances; the guiding principle is always the best interests of the child…. [I]n the Commonwealth ‘the best interests analysis is a child-centered one that focuses on the specific needs and interests of a child and how these might best be met.’”

Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30 must be based on the best interests of the child, expressly including whether the move will affect the child’s emotional, physical, developmental, and educational needs, and whether the quality of the child’s life will be improved. Yannas thus provides authority for the proposition that a modification (such as relocation or related custody adjustment) must protect and promote a child’s academic, emotional, and developmental interests. The case is accurately cited for that general best‑interests standard, even though it is a removal case rather than a generic modification case.

Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
